history.content:
I’m happy to report today that our Champion balloon is still alive and well. 
Over the past 24 hours it spent its time over Kazakhastan, heading in a south-east-east path. This is a bit more south, and slower velocity than predicted. 
Cory Hall is located at latitude 37.87 North and longitude 122.25 west.  The balloon, as of 3 hours ago was at around lattitude 47 North and longitude 64East.  Looking at the difference we get 186.25 — which means that our balloon crossed a major landmark— passed halfway around the world (similar latitude though), and is now closer to Berkeley from the west than from the east. 
I had a question over email, on how we maintain radio contact with our balloon over the Ukraine, or where it is now. The answer is we don’t maintain direct radio contact. We leverage an existing system of receivers that amateurs use to monitor radio waves propagation around the world — called WSPR. These stations receive our signal and report it to a database that can be probed, downloaded or displayed if you visit wsprnet.org.  Below is a map of all the stations that received our signal and reported it. What is amazing, is that our signal was picked up not only in Europe, but also in North America and Hawaii— about 11,500KM away— remember that our balloon payload is 26 grams, is solar powered and transmits 10milli Watts!
The new predicted path over the next 86 hours is attached as well. 
More updates tomorrow. 
— Miki
history.subject: EECS Balloons day #15: Major landmark reached -- more than halfway around the world(!)
